metadata.case_name: Union of India & Ors. v. M.L. Capoor & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 614-617 of 1971 and Civil Appeal No. 695 of 1971

facts.text: M.L. Capoor and K.N. Misra, members of U.P. State Police Service, brought on select list for promotion to Indian Police Service in 1961 and 1962, officiated as Superintendents of Police on cadre posts.
Ganesh Singh Seth and Basant Kumar Joshi, members of U.P. Civil Executive Service, brought on select list for Indian Administrative Service in 1961 and 1962, officiated as District Magistrates.
Respondents continued on select lists until 1968 list prepared in December 1967, when they were dropped from the list.
In 1968 select list, number of junior officers (e.g., 10 juniors to K.N. Misra, 19 to M.L. Capoor, 14 to others) added who were not in 1967 list; some lower in 1967 list appointed in 1968.

Selection Committee gave uniform reason for dropping respondents: 'On an overall assessment, the records of these officers are not such as to justify their appointment to the Indian Administrative Service/Indian Police Service at this stage in preference to those selected.'
State Government terminated officiating appointments of respondents and reverted them to substantive posts in State services.

Respondents filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court challenging reversion orders; writs referred to Division Bench, allowed along with special appeals, quashing 1968 select lists and reversion orders.
Appeals to Supreme Court on certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court was right in interpreting Regulation 5(2) of Promotion Regulations that seniority is dominant factor for inclusion in select list, merit and suitability secondary.
Whether State Government competent to terminate officiating appointments under Rule 9 of Cadre Rules without direction from Central Government.
Whether principles of natural justice require notice and opportunity to respondents before supersession or removal from select list.
Whether function of Selection Committee is quasi-judicial requiring lis, hearing etc.
Whether reasons recorded by Selection Committee under Reg. 5(5) for supersession adequate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Selection for inclusion in list based on merit and suitability in all respects with due regard to seniority; merit governing, seniority secondary only when merits equal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Reg. 5(2) of Indian Administrative Service/Indian Police Service (Appointment by Promotion) Regulations, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Annual review requires fresh assessment of all eligible candidates; field of selection comprises all eligible members.
State Government as appointing authority under R.9(2) Cadre Rules has power to terminate officiating appointments.
No right to notice before supersession as inclusion in select list gives only inchoate right; no vested right for next year.
Selection process administrative, not quasi-judicial; akin to examination, no lis between candidates.

respondent_arguments.text: Seniority dominant factor, merit/suitability secondary; junior only if senior unfit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Reg. 5(2) as interpreted by High Court

respondent_arguments.text: Review/revision not fresh selection from all; prior list members protected unless deterioration or exceptional juniors.
Notice and opportunity required before supersession as per natural justice.
Only Central Government can terminate under R.9(3); State lacks power without direction.

court_reasoning.text: Reg. 5(2) means merit and suitability governing consideration, seniority secondary; only equal when merits roughly equal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court wrong; selection primarily on merit-cum-suitability with due regard to seniority.

court_reasoning.text: Annual review requires fresh assessment of merit/suitability of all eligible; field includes all, not limited to previous list.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No go-bye to 'all' in Reg. 4(1); fresh list every year.

court_reasoning.text: State Government has power to terminate as appointing authority; R.9(3) enables Central direction but does not denude State power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power of appointment carries termination power absent contrary provision.

court_reasoning.text: No notice required for supersession; inclusion gives inchoate right only for currency year; no vested right next year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not expedient to extend natural justice to expectations.

court_reasoning.text: Selection administrative, not quasi-judicial; no lis, akin to examination by service records.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No hearing each candidate vs others impracticable.

court_reasoning.text: Reasons under Reg. 5(5) inadequate; stock phrase not disclosing comparative assessment or rational nexus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandatory provision not complied; reasons must link facts to conclusion.

court_reasoning.text: Inclusion test competitive/comparative among all eligible; merit governs, seniority one factor; then arrange by seniority per Reg. 5(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not minimal pass mark; best talent selected.

holdings.text: Selection under Reg. 5(2) based primarily on merit and suitability with due regard to seniority.
State Government competent to terminate officiating appointments.
No notice/opportunity required before supersession in selection process.
1968 select lists invalid for non-compliance with Reg. 5(5) as reasons inadequate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sant Ram Sharma v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Promotion to selection posts primarily on merit, not seniority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mir Ghulam v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Preparation of list under Reg. 5(1) primarily on merit and suitability.

precedents_cited.case_name: N.P. Mathur v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Selection to posts on merit irrespective of seniority.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Kraipak v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Administrative functions must be fair, but no quasi-judicial hearing here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Administrative Service (Appointment by Promotion) Regulations, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs preparation, review, revision of select lists; merit-seniority criteria; reasons for supersession.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Appointment by Promotion) Regulations, 1955
Indian Administrative Service/Indian Police Service (Recruitment) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: 25% posts by promotion; basis of selection.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Administrative Service/Indian Police Service (Cadre) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Temporary appointments to cadre posts; termination powers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality, fair treatment in service; no punishment without hearing.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; 1968 select lists and reversion orders quashed by High Court upheld due to inadequate reasons under Reg. 5(5); parties to bear own costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of 1968 select lists and reversion orders upheld.
outcome.costs: Parties bear their own costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: "The selection for inclusion in such list shall be based on merit and suitability in all respects with due regard to seniority."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key phrase from Reg. 5(2) interpreted as merit primary.

key_quotes.text: Merit and suitability in all respects should be the governing consideration and that seniority should play only a secondary role.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of Reg. 5(2).

key_quotes.text: The rubber-stamp reason given mechanically for the supersession of each officer does not amount to reasons.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for invalidating lists; non-compliance with Reg. 5(5).

key_quotes.text: It is not expedient to extend the horizon of natural justice... to the twilight zone of mere expectations.
key_quotes.speaker: court
